und.safe_value: Shades of red show where  annual average temperatures were up to 4° Fahrenheit warmer than the average from 1981–2010. Shades of blue show where average temperature for the year was up to 4° Fahrenheit cooler than average. The darker the color, the larger the difference from average. White and very light areas were close to their long-term average temperature.

und.safe_value: Checking how temperatures around the globe compare to their long-term average for each year gives climate scientists a way to monitor Earth's overall temperature. Though some areas are cooler than usual and other areas are warmer than usual each year, overall average temperatures show a decades-long trend of increasing.
und.value: Checking how temperatures around the globe compare to their long-term average for each year gives climate scientists a way to monitor Earth's overall temperature. Though some areas are cooler than usual and other areas are warmer than usual each year, overall average temperatures show a decades-long trend of increasing.

und.safe_value: From NOAA View: Merged Land and Ocean Surface Temperature version 3.5.4 (which is composed of the Global Historical Climatology Network-Monthly version 3.2.2 and ERSST version 3b)  http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/ersst/merge.php
und.value: From NOAA View: Merged Land and Ocean Surface Temperature version 3.5.4 (which is composed of the Global Historical Climatology Network-Monthly version 3.2.2 and ERSST version 3b)  http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/ersst/merge.php

und.safe_value: Temperature readings come from weather stations in the Global Historical Climate Network. Departure from Average values are calculated by averaging daily temperatures observed at individual stations, and subtracting them from the long-term average temperature for each location. To produce the final map, visualization specialists use an averaging process to smooth color transitions and fill blank spaces.
und.value: Temperature readings come from weather stations in the Global Historical Climate Network. Departure from Average values are calculated by averaging daily temperatures observed at individual stations, and subtracting them from the long-term average temperature for each location. To produce the final map, visualization specialists use an averaging process to smooth color transitions and fill blank spaces.
Colors show where average annual temperatures were warmer or cooler than their long-term average temperature. The darker the color, the larger the difference from the average temperature.
und.safe_value: Colors show where average annual temperatures were warmer or cooler than their long-term average temperature. The darker the color, the larger the difference from the average temperature.
